patterns.pattern: First-time contributors with missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, has_tests, ci_green) face a persistent -7-8% penalty that compounds other rejection signals
Authors with perfect or near-perfect prior merge rates (≥80% across ≥1 prior PR) receive +15-25% credibility bonus that substantially overrides scope/metadata concerns
XS and S size labels act as compensatory signals (+2-4% boost), correlating with 26-28% merge rates and partially mitigating metadata penalties and weak author credentials
L and XL size labels function as deterministic rejection signals overriding category/type compensations, correlating with 15-20% merge rates regardless of other positive signals
Fix-type changes receive consistent +10-20% boost over feature-type additions, particularly in high-priority categories
Maintainer labels or high-priority credibility signals (+15-25% bonus) enable multi-component/multi-category scope acceptance that would otherwise trigger -25-30% scope creep penalty
Authors with established high-volume history (50+ prior PRs) retain moderate merge likelihood (25-30%) despite below-baseline merge rates, indicating persistence/credibility signal
Low-merge-history authors (0% merge rate across 5+ prior PRs, is_low_merge_author=true) face near-deterministic rejection (~0-5% likelihood) that cannot be overcome by single-PR compensatory signals

Authors with above-baseline merge rates (+5-10% delta over 24% baseline) substantially mitigate missing metadata penalties and enable moderate-to-strong merge likelihood even without explicit size labels
Critical-path infrastructure changes (agents, gateway, routing) receive +15-25% category uplift, partially compensating for first-time contributor or weak credibility status in narrow-scope fixes

Documentation-only PRs from first-time contributors have depressed baseline (20-30% merge rate) that requires compensatory signals (XS size, high-priority infrastructure context, issue reference) to reach baseline
Multi-component scope (≥3 categories/areas) imposes -25-30% penalty for weak/first-time authors but is substantially mitigated by maintainer status or established above-baseline merge rate (≥30%)
Narrow, focused scope (single component/channel, single logical fix) provides consistent +5-10% boost that accumulates with other positive signals
Authors demonstrating persistent submission history (4+ prior PRs) receive +2-5% persistence/commitment signal even with below-baseline merge rates, indicating credibility independent of merge rate
Channel plugin work without maintainer approval or experienced contributor status faces elevated -10-15% risk penalty, reducing baseline acceptance likelihood
Security-related or critical-path fixes receive preferential +5-10% treatment from established authors (≥2 prior PRs) independent of category uplift, signaling infrastructure priority
Explicit issue references provide +5-10% specificity boost, particularly valuable for first-time contributors to overcome credibility gaps
